awd_titl_txt: Engineering Scholars Program: Fostering the Next Generation of STEM Leaders
awd_abstract_narration:
This "NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Program (S-STEM)" project at Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU), an HBCU, will serve the financial, academic, and career needs of talented low income students pursuing bachelor degrees in engineering, computer science, or technology. The project will directly support 30 students with one cohort of 15 students beginning in year 1 and a second cohort of 15 students beginning in year 2.  Scholarships will help ease the financial burdens that many minority students face, and targeted support structures will help ensure student success. A multi-pronged strategy consisting of cohort building, academic support, professional development, mentoring, and individual advisory teams for students will be used improve student learning and increase retention and graduation rates. Congruent with NSF S-STEM program goals, the project will add to the University's and national efforts to increase the number of minority students graduating with STEM degrees thus supporting a more diverse and competent United States workforce.

A fundamental goal of the project is to increase the number of underrepresented minority students who graduate with undergraduate degrees in STEM fields and to enhance the preparedness of these students for diverse STEM workforce career paths and graduate education. A research study examining student motivation, self-efficacy, and STEM identity development will be an integral component of the project. The research will utilize an interpretive narrative design and will involve qualitative studies focusing on the activities and experiences of program participants. Findings will provide insights into interventions that are successful in helping minority students navigate the path to engineering and other STEM careers and flourish in those careers. An evaluation plan using a mixed quantitative and qualitative methods approach will measure the effectiveness of the program and its impact on student performance and graduation and retention efforts.  Tangible data and results will be generated from the project that support recruitment, retention, and workforce diversification and broadening participation efforts for this student demographic. Key outcomes of the project will be broadly disseminated through a variety of venues.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF S-STEM grant awarded to Prairie View A&M University, a Historically Black University, supported the financial, academic, and career needs of 50 talented low-income students to achieve bachelor's degrees in engineering and computer science. ﻿The overarching goal was to increase the number of underrepresented minority students who graduate with undergraduate degrees in STEM fields and to increase the preparedness of these students for diverse career paths. More than 90% of the participants were from underrepresented groups. The undergraduate majors included civil engineering, chemical engineering, electrical engineering, computer engineering, mechanical engineering, and computer science. Students received a scholarship based on need up to $5,000 per academic year. The project utilized a student support model that consisted of cohort building, supplemental instruction, mid-semester reviews, professional development, and mentoring. Students participated in a number of program activities each semester that supported these strategies.

We were able to meet our project goals and objectives related to student success.  More than 80% of the students completed their degree within five years and more than 90% received full-time jobs in STEM or enrolled in STEM graduate programs after graduation.

Another goal of the project was to contribute to the literature on retention and workforce issues impacting African-American students through a research study that examined student motivation in pursuing a STEM career and STEM identity development. Our data suggests that high school experiences are the most critical factor in terms of motivating students to pursue STEM disciplines. This highlights the need for continued STEM programs at the K-12 level. Study results also highlighted the role of internships in providing motivation for students to persist in STEM degree programs and increasing confidence and identity. The lack of diversity in the internship experience was a sentiment shared by most students.

African Americans continue to remain one of the most underrepresented minority groups in STEM-related fields. Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) play a critical role in the production of undergraduate STEM degrees awarded to African Americans, and as a result, HBCUs are ideally situated to lead efforts to increase the representation and preparedness of minority students in the STEM workforce. This project contained a multidisciplinary team of educators and administrators experienced in STEM education, the administration of student scholarships, the organization and administration of student programs and support services, and the evaluation of program outcomes. A student support model has been created that can be used to impact all students at the university and other universities that serve this population of students to increase retention and persistence in STEM degree programs, particularly engineering.
